course_title: Understanding and Caring for Those Affected by Loss

learning_outcomes.description: Understand the social, intrapersonal, and biological factors that influence reactions to loss and grief responses across the life cycle
Describe major definitions and theoretical models related to loss and grief.
Differentiate complicated grieving patterns and comorbidity issues from uncomplicated grieving patterns
Develop clinical skills in assessment and evidence-based interventions for working with loss and grief.
Recognise your own personal experiences of loss and grief that may affect your practice
Critically reflect on the influence of culture and diversity in shaping responses to loss and consider how this understanding informs professional practice

assessments.task_description:
This assessment piece takes the form of a  Personal Exploration to be completed and submitted in 2 parts. 


You are asked to engage in two conversations about loss with a person of your own choosing and respond to a set of questions about each conversation. Your conversation can be another student but is often preferable for it to be someone outside the university. It is vital that you are to choose someone whom you find easy to trust.


Both you and your companion are asked to think about and discuss three losses from your lives. Please discuss the procedure (instructions) with your companion before you have the first conversation. They may prefer to think about their responses before you meet and even make some notes. However, only your responses need to be submitted via Turnitin for assessment purposes. Detailed instructions are provided on Blackboard in the course manual.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You are asked to submit your responses via Turnitin. Part 1 and part 2 are submitted separately on different dates. Please read the instructions provided in the Course Manual.

assessments.assessment_title: Case report - A study of grief and loss
assessments.due_date:
7/05/2026 2:00 pm

Please hand the signed participant consent form to the Course Coordinator prior to submitting your assessment.
assessments.task_description:
GENERAL TASK DESCRIPTION

For this task you’ll be taking a deep dive into case formulation in the context of loss by writing a professional case report based on an interview with a real person. This is your opportunity to bring together everything you’re learning – clinical interviewing, diagnostic reasoning, psychological formulation and ethical practice – into a concise, structured report.

Your case report should demonstrate ethical and professional conduct, integrate client experience with psychological theory, and provide evidence of sound clinical judgement. The final product should be concise, coherent, and suitable for sharing with other professionals. As part of the learning process, you are also asked to reflect on your experience of undertaking this task

Page/ Word limit: Maximum 7 pages comprising a maximum of 5 pages for the case report, 1 page for a formulation diagram, and 1 page for self-reflection. The length includes in-text citations. Any reference list is not included in the page limit.

For detailed instructions, including required formatting, please see the course manual on Blackboard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please submit your report via Turnitin. You should provide a hard copy of the signed consent form to the Course Coordinator prior to submission

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Fact Sheet and 5 minute presentation on an area of loss
assessments.due_date:
1/05/2026 - 25/05/2026

Presentations will take place during the week 12 and week 13 workshops. You will be allocated a presentation time by the course coordinator.
assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, you will explore a specific area of loss that holds significance in psychological practice. Your task involves two components

A visually engaging Fact Sheet, designed for use by practicing psychologists: (word count = max 1000 words; 15%)

A 5-minute professional presentation on this chosen topic (10%)

Presentations will take place during the week 12 and week 13 workshops. You will be allocated a presentation time by the course coordinator.

Fact sheets are due at the same time as your presentation. Please bring handouts of your Fact Sheet for your colleagues. Note: You are not asked to use PowerPoint slides for this presentation, instead you are asked to refer to your Fact Sheet handouts. You are also asked to submit a copy of your Fact Sheet via turn it in for assessment.

By completing this task, you will further develop your identity as a reflective practitioner, capable of synthesizing research, evaluating interventions, and communicating effectively with professional audiences.

To ensure a diverse range of topics across the cohort, please confirm your topic with the Course Coordinator by the end of week 9.

For detailed instructions, please consult the course manual available of Blackboard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your Fact Sheet via Turnitin before class on your presentation date. You are asked to bring handouts to class for your colleagues
